userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials from Washington and Lee University Special Collections are made available for use in research, teaching, and private study, pursuant to U.S. Copyright law. The user assumes full responsibility for any use of the materials, including but not limited to, infringement of copyright and publication rights of reproduced materials. Any materials used should be fully credited with the source. Permission for publication of this material, in part or in full, must be secured with the Head of Special Collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Preferred citation: [Identification of item], George A. Baxter Papers, WLU Coll 0003, Special Collections Leyburn Library, Washington and Lee University, Lexington, VA.
In some cases the citation format may vary. Please contact Special Collections staff to verify the appropriate format.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Baxter Family Correspondence and papers, 1797-1918 were a gift of Mary Coulling and Martha Coulling.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Includes letters from G.A. Baxter to his wife, Anne Fleming Baxter, and 104 letters from miscellaneous correspondents dealing with the Union Theological Seminary and Presbyterian affairs; reminiscences of Louise Baxter, and letters to her; citations, certificates, and business receipts.Includes three generations of Baxter family correspondence. Also includes a biography of George A. Baxter, sermons written by George A. Baxter, assorted Presbyterian newspaper articles, and three photographsFamily papers reflect the social life of 19th century Virginia, including a personal recipe book, as well as a folder on the genealogy of the Fleming family and a letter to Louisa Baxter from a missionary's wife in China.
Other correspondents include Alexander Tedford Barclay, Louisa Baxter, William Brown, William Henry Foote, Edward Graham, Samuel L. Graham, Hugh Blair Grigsby, and William Swann Plumer.

did.materialspec: Letter dated June 9, 1851, from Anne S. Rice of Rice Hill, Virginia to Elizabeth Baxter concerning a former Rice family slave, Hannah, and her condition in Liberia. Hannah was emancipated by the Rice family and sent to Liberia.

did.materialspec: Letter dated November 21, 1843 from Anne S. Rice to Nancy M. Baxter concerning the health of enslaved person Hannah, formerly owned by the Baxter Family and then by the Rice family.

did.unittitle: Sidney Smith Baxter- Correspondence and Book

origination.label: Creator
origination.persname: See, Charles S. M. (Charles Sydney Mathews), 1826-1903

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folder includes letters written by Charles S. M. See to his aunt Louisa Baxter during the American Civil War. Includes description of early war situation in Tucker (W. Va.) and Augusta County, Virginia. One letter details the death of his brother George Baxter See in a Confederate hospital in 1864. Another details Charles' capture and confinement in both the old Capital Prison in Washington D.C. and Johnson's Island Prison in Ohio. This letter also mentions President Abraham Lincoln's assassination and the surprisingly cordial relations of Unionists and Secessionists in the immediate post war period in Tucker County, West Virginia.

did.unittitle: Letter from George Addison Baxter to Anne Fleming on the death of William Graham
